questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following viruses is related to etiology of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC). EBV antigens are currently being used to screen high-risk populations. The antigens being used 
are • Viral capsid antigen (VCA) - highly sensitive for NPC • Early antigen (EA) - highly specific for NPC.

questions.question: Question 2: What is nasopharyngeal carcinoma also known as?
questions.explanation:
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also known as Guangdong tumor. This is because the Southern 
Chinese province of Guangdong has the highest prevalence of the tumor. Chinese, especially from southeastern China (Canton), have a higher genetic susceptibility to 
nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC). Chinese emigrants are also genetically more susceptible, however, 
the susceptibility falls in subsequent generations. Other South-East Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and people of Mongoloid origin 
are also more susceptible.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma 
in high-risk populations of China?
questions.explanation:
Human papillomavirus is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma in 
high-risk populations of China. EBV (Epstein Barr virus) causes nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 
HPV(Human papillomavirus) causes inverted papilloma of the nose. High-risk populations such as the Chinese have a very high incidence of nasopharyngeal 
carcinoma. The following factors have been implicated in the pathogenesis: • Burning of incense or wood (polycyclic hydrocarbons) • Consumption of preserved salted fish (nitrosamines) • Vitamin C deficient diet (vitamin C blocks nitrosification of amines and is thus protective) 511

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with a family history of nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with nasal discharge 
and a painless lump in the upper neck. On posterior rhinoscopy, where will you most 
commonly expect to find a mass originating from?
questions.explanation: The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature of 
nasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by- • Hearing loss • Nasal obstruction • Epistaxis • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the 
cranial nerves. • Headache • Earache • Neck pain • Weight loss

questions.question:
Question 6: A housewife from rural Tripura with a past history of infectious mononucleosis presents with 
complaints of double vision and a neck swelling that has progressively increased in size. She 
also gives a history of nasal discharge and is annoyed that her husband is recently 
complaining of a change in her voice. What is the most likely speech pattern observed here?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario of exposure to EBV, progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal 
discharge, diplopia (involvement of cranial nerve VI), and change in voice is suggestive of 
nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The most likely speech pattern, in this case, is rhinolalia clausa or 
denasal speech, due to obstruction of the nasopharynx by the tumor. 512 
Sold by @itachibot Rhinolalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words resonated in the nasal cavity and is 
usually seen due to blockage of nose or nasopharynx Other nasal symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma are: • Nasal obstruction • Nasal discharge • Epistaxis Option B- Rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal voice) is seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency. Option C- Puberphonia is the persistence of prepubertal voice into adolescence or adulthood. Option D- Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess 
or quinsy.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 45-year-old Chinese woman presents with left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal 
obstruction, and left-sided hearing loss. What is the most likely cause for hearing loss in this 
case?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hearing loss, in this case, 
is due to serous otitis media. Serous otitis media is caused due to mechanical obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor. 
The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise suspicion of 
nasopharyngeal growth.

questions.question:
Question 8: 508 
Sold by @itachibot You have sent a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma and hearing loss for tympanometry. 
Which of the following tympanometry curves do you expect to find?
questions.explanation:
Type B tympanometry curve is expected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Due to mechanical 
obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor, serous otitis media occurs, causing conductive 
hearing loss.

questions.question:
Question 9: You are an ENT resident on a clinical elective in Guangzhou. You receive a patient with 
painless cervical lymphadenopathy, conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facial 
pain. Which of the following do you see here?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter’s triad/Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter’s 
syndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Trotter’s triad consists of: • Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigeminal 
nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain. • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal 
asymmetry. Option A - Samter’s triad seen in ethmoidal polyps consists of nasal polypi, asthma, and Aspirin 
intolerance 513 
Sold by @itachibot Option C - van der Hoeve syndrome is seen in otosclerosis consists of osteogenesis imperfecta, 
otosclerosis, and blue sclera Option D - Kartagener syndrome consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliary 
dyskinesia.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following branches of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter’s triad?
questions.explanation:
The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter’s triad. Trotter’s triad seen 
in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It consists of: • Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigeminal 
nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain. • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.

questions.question:
Question 11: A known case of right-sided nasopharyngeal carcinoma now presents with drooping of 
eyelids, reduced sweating on the right side of the face, and constricted pupil. Involvement of 
which of the following structures leads to these features?
questions.explanation:
Involvement of the sympathetic chain causes these features. The given clinical scenario is 
suggestive of Horner’s syndrome secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma involving the cervical 
sympathetic chain. Horner’s syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and ipsilateral anhydrosis. Option B - Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) involvement presents as ipsilateral temporoparietal 
neuralgia. Option C - Cranial nerve VI (Abducens nerve) involvement causes ophthalmoplegia Option D - Jugular foramen involvement causes paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, causing 
jugular foramen syndrome, also seen in acoustic neuroma and glomus jugulare.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following WHO categories does differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell 
carcinoma of the nasopharynx belong to?
questions.explanation:
Differentiated non-keratinized squamous cell carcinoma is categorized as Type 2. WHO Classification based on Histopathology: Note- The latest WHO classification has combined types 2 and 3 into one category: 
Non-keratinizing Squamous cell carcinoma which is further subclassified into differentiated and

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with persistent cervical lymphadenopathy now came with spontaneous epistaxis. 
Nasal endoscopy showed a mass arising from the fossa of Rosenmuller. Biopsy from the mass 
revealed a keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. What is the treatment of choice in this 
case?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The treatment of choice is 
radiotherapy. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional 
disease is invariably radiotherapy. Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone. Stage III and IV are treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can be 
neoadjuvant, concurrent, or adjuvant to radiotherapy. 515
